recipient_justification: Milestone (Y1.M1) ($632,330); (Y1.M2) ($563,958):Detailed Results: Document Exit Criteria were met, including performance metrics, data, graphics, and pipeline where appropriate. Ensure the Milestone is met in full. The exit criteria for this quarter are to generate the design documents for the version of the tools that will be produced in the next quarter. We developed V0.1 design documents for CHARMonator, CHARMGPT, CHARMonizer, FHIR-HOSE, CHARMomics and Twinsight.  Current design documents focus on achieving the next milestones as indicated, while also being mindful of future needs. Hurdles & Solutions: The largest challenge for the group thus far has been ensuring the entire team across all projects is organized and informed. There is a 6 hour difference between the time zones across the group. We have established 2 separate weekly meetings to accommodate all the groups.  Thus far this has been sufficient to drive the projects and seen by the completion of all 6 design documents.
agency_lead_justification: The payment is approved for tasks performed as specified in Milestone Y1.M1 (Complete the architecture design for all CHARM components) and Y1.M2 (Develop initial versions of all CHARM components) in support of the ARPA-H BDF Toolbox program to consolidate healthcare and research data from various health disciplines and resolve inconsistencies in data storage and sharing.

recipient_justification:
This award is to conduct all the research tasks related to the Cancer Grand Challenges Project entitled  PROMINENT: Discovering the molecular signatures of cancer PROMotion to INform prevENTion.

The main objective of the PROMINENT project is to identify the mechanisms that control mutant cells within normal human tissues, and to elucidate the precise mechanisms by which cancer promoting agents stimulate the conversion of these cells to neoplastic growth. We are one of the teams involved in that project, leading the WP5: Deriving molecular signatures of cancer promotion.

We are using ultradeep sequencing and a set of computational tools developed de novo or adapted for their use of this new type of data to probe the clonal landscape of several normal tissues across individuals with different histories of exposures and lifetime cancer risk.

The requested funds cover i) the recruitment of several Postdoctoral Researchers and Technicians, ii) experimental tasks related with ultradeep sequencing library preparation (specifically to acquire laboratory supplies and cover sequencing services), and iii) publication of results. These funds are thus key to fulfill the identification of molecular signatures of cancer promotion that WP5 is tasked for within the PROMINENT project.

recipient_justification: The funds were withdrawn in alignment with our Notice of Award, FAIN U01AI178756, for work performed by PPD Development LP employees and a vendor (Digital Infuzion, Inc) during the April 2025 accounting period. The Transplantation Statistical and Clinical Coordinating Center (T-SCCC) team provides overall Scientific Leadership, Statistical and Programming services, and Project Management support across the Clinical Trials in Organ Transplantation in Children and Adults (CTOT-CA), Immune Tolerance Network (ITN), and select Investigator Initiated Clinical Trials (IICTs) studies supported under this award. Additionally, for the CTOT-CA studies and currently (1) IICT, the T-SCCC also provides the following: the Learning Management System, utilized to assign and track site staff study protocol training; the Preclarus sample tracking system; and sample collection supplies and reagents for each study. The T-SCCC also provides regulatory support to create and maintain the CTOT-CA, ITN, and IICT study clinicaltrials.gov records. Digital Infuzion, Inc., provides a web-based collaboration portal used to house study materials and system links utilized by the participating clinical sites, NIAID, and other key study stakeholders. The services provided align with the goals and aims of the T-SCCC as outlined in our original application and referenced in our annual RPPR.

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $473,785.76 on the DHHS – NIH grant number 4UH3DA050323-02. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period April 6, 2025, through April 26, 2025 for expenses approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Cannabidiol in the treatment of opioid use disorder. 
Personnel 	$214,005.04
Fringe Benefit	$66,341.56
Indirect Cost	$193,439.16
Total		$473,785.76

It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with RFA-DA-19-002, 45 CFR Part 75 and the NIH Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

recipient_justification: The goal of this research is to understand how variation in the number of oligosaccharide chains attached to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) affect fertility and other age-related issues in women, such as osteoporosis. This integrated research program will study FSH binding to its receptor, altering receptor oligomerization, activating different signal initiators, and stimulating different pathways both in cells and in whole organisms. The potential translational outcomes of this research is potentially improved drugs for infertility treatment or for ameliorating the bone-damaging effects of age-related increased FSH in the blood.” The approved budget categories are: Salaries, Fringe Benefits, Travel, Supplies, Consultant Services, Sub awards, Other Direct Costs, Publication Costs, ADP/Computer Services and Indirect Costs and are necessary to accomplish the specific aims/goals of the project.

recipient_justification: CASEL serves as a coordinating center for a network of tobacco researchers funded by the FDA’s Center for Tobacco Products. These funds were used for ongoing CASEL operations in accordance with CASEL’s primary aim of accelerating research in this field, as defined in our original application and incorporated into each grant year’s NoA. Activities carried out during the period for which funds are requested included: providing scientific expertise through steering committees and other groups; hosting and updating a website for centralized communication and scientific dissemination; leading and facilitating collaborative work through special interest and working groups; supporting data sharing, harmonization, and analysis; supporting the use of common core measures; developing and updating resources; hosting a monthly scientific webinar series; preparing and disseminating a bi-weekly digest of community announcements, opportunities, and events; supporting career development activities; and managing the Opportunity Fund through which small grants are awarded to researchers to answer specific high-priority research questions.

recipient_justification: February deliverables in accordance with agreement AY2AX000007, tasks 1 - 6
agency_lead_justification:
This payment is required for an Other Transaction Agreement (OTA) to support the Investor Catalyst (IC) Hub activities supporting ARPANET-Health (ANH) that were conducted in February. These activities added benefits to the government by the performers partnering with ARPA-H to support programs in biomedical and health research breakthroughs, delivering transformative, financially sustainable, and broadly applicable health solutions. The IC Hub advanced key program, network, and R&D project priorities, supporting Tasks 1-4 and 6 of the scope for this agreement, to include:

Task 1: Program Management – Highlight: Continued development of resource library for member portal
Task 2: Consortium Capabilities and Support Services – Highlight: Conducted RNA Biomanufacturing Market Demand Survey
Task 3: Manage Network – Highlight: Submitted concept note for GEONOVA program and conducted kick-off call for SAPPHIRE program
Task 4: Physical Location – Highlight: Supported ARPA-H return to office to the IC Hub and maintaining office readiness at the primary hub location
Task 6: Project Support – Highlight: 60 project deliverables processed this month under 24 project awards

recipient_justification: In alignment with our proposal and Year 1 progress report, personnel costs for this period were spent on planning and preparing for human subjects related work. This included onboarding all performance sites and CBOs and introducing them to the mobile tech-enabled CBPR methods for data collection (Streetwyze), submitting our IRB and collaborating on our goals and strategies for recruitment and data collection. We developed our Lived Experience Data Collection program (Aim 1) and performed necessary platform maintenance and improvement to Streetwyze. We also began developing our community sensemaking protocol for creating community-generated factors/scales, and identified next steps for creating agent-based models in YR2 and YR3. The work our team performed was clearly severable from Human Subjects work, as we did not begin any outreach or data collection with participants, but instead set up the necessary structures, systems, and protocols to be able to do so successfully in Year 2.

recipient_justification:
This grant was recently transferred to us (LC Acquisition, LLC) from another entity (Axcend, LLC). We spent about 8 months working with your office to formally get the grant transferred to the new entity. In that time, we did not have access to draw any NIH grant funds, but research & grant-related work continued on. The $306,569.41 is a culmination of costs already absorbed by the company in the period in which we were not able to draw from the grant. The grant funds were finally released last week for us to draw from, thus the large sum all at once. 
 
I would like to stress the urgency & importance of receiving this deposit, as the formal grant transition process has really put a financial strain on our company while we have continued to perform research. I can provide more details & granular cost support if needed. 

The $306,569.41 is broken down as follows:

$88,832 in personnel labor costs.

$90,000 in equipment purchases (high pressure pumping systems).

$74,406.26 in materials and supplies purchases (Chemical solvents & test cmpds, column preparation materials, cartridge electronic components & boards, detector optics & housings, solid phase extraction materials)

$53,333 in external consulting services.

recipient_justification: The TRANSFORM team made strong progress across core project areas, including data acquisition, recruitment, modelling development (Aims 1 and 2), and dissemination of early findings. Key objectives—such as establishing sub-award and data-sharing agreements and initiating data linkage processes—were achieved across all participating Sites. Project funds were used to support the finalisation of sub-award contracts, data application submissions, and regular coordination between Aim Leads and Site data teams to align data processing and modelling requirements. These efforts have laid a solid foundation for continued work in Year 2. To date, the project has produced 12 journal articles in top-tier journals, including The Lancet Public Health, Addiction, and The International Journal of Epidemiology, demonstrating significant early outputs and the impactful use of Year 1 funding.

recipient_justification: Payment is justified IAW with applicable SOW Tasks 1, 3, 4, and 6, and support of the ACTR program, as accepted by the Agreements Officer, for the CX Hub program.
agency_lead_justification:
This payment is required for an Other Transaction Agreement (OTA) to support the Customer Experience (CX) Hub activities supporting ARPANET-Health (ANH) that were conducted in February. These activities added benefits to the government by the performers partnering with ARPA-H to support programs providing research and development (R&D) that accelerate better health outcomes for all Americans. The CX Hub advanced key program, network, and R&D project priorities, supporting Tasks 1-4 and 6 of the scope for this agreement, to include:

Task 1: Program Management – Highlight: Reviewed lessons learned from projects, focusing on challenges related to particular industries and sectors within the consortium.
Task 4: Physical Location – Highlight: Supported ARPA-H return to office to the CX Hub and maintaining office readiness at the primary hub location
Task 6: Project Support – Highlight: Distributed solicitation to consortium members for new program, and coordinated FAQs with ARPA-H stakeholders for appropriate responses to consortium members.

recipient_justification:
The amount requested corresponds to expenses made for this project between 06/01/2024 and 03/31/2025.
Per details :

Personnel salaries : $ 113,523.66
 - GIUA Gabriele (PhD): $ 53,260.70
 - MEYER Judith (engineer assistant) : $ 41,907.24
 - OZDEMIR Dersu (PhD student): $ 15,770.40
 - Internship students :  $ 2,585.32

- Emmanuel Darcq, senior scientist at INSERM. His contribution to the project helped him to get a permanent position at INSERM and will help him towards independence for his future career. He presented some of the work presented at symposiums some of the work at the International narcotic research conference (July 2024), the addiction Gordon Research Conference and chair a session (August 2024), at the European winter brain conference (EWCBR, January 2025) and co-organized an EMBO global lecture at Mohali India (March 2025). He has gradually taken the lead on this project. He will also present his work at the Mediterranean Neuroscience Conference (June 2025) and International narcotic research conference (July 2025).
 
- Dersu Ozdemir, International Master student from Paris, joined our laboratory and the UNISTRA in march 2021 to start her PhD. She works full time on this project and has established the animal model to study the role of habenular MOR neurons on Naloxone responses in naïve and dependent animals. Now, she is working on fiber photometry and chemogenetic experiments to finalize her work. She obtained a first author paper in Scientific reports and presented her work at ECNP 2024 in September. She defended her PhD in March 2025 and this phase is critical to the development of her future career, as she wish to pursue with a postdoctoral position. She will also present her work at the International narcotic research conference (July 2025).
 
- Chiara Ebner, International Master student from Ulm in Germany, joined our laboratory and the UNISTRA in January 2024 to start her PhD. She works full time on the characterization of habenular MOR neurons to determine whether medial and lateral habenular MOR-expressing neurons have different physiological roles or represent a unique functionally defined cross-habenular neuronal population modulating affective states. She recently used spatial transcriptomic to determine specific neuronal population of habenular neurons. She will also present her work at the International narcotic research conference (July 2025).
 
- Gabriele Giua, a recent PhD from Marseille, France (Lab of Dr Olivier Manzoni), has joined our laboratory in April 2024 as postdoctoral fellow to work on MOR neurons manipulation and calcium-activity characterization using fiber photometry. He is taking over on-going work from Dersu Ozdemir (contract will finish at the end of June 2025) on habenula projections, with a focus on LH. He will also present his work at the International narcotic research conference (July 2025).
 
- Judith Meyer, research assistant and mouse manager, joined our team in September 2023. She is in charge of all mutant mouse colonies of our lab and dedicates a large part of her time to this project. This training will help her develop as a project manager in the future, with the goal to obtain a permanent position.

Materials and supplies : $ 50,608.08
Other (animals, publishing) : $ 47,560.46
Travel (conference ECNP, EWCBR, SfN International symposium signal and circuit) : $ 7,241.36
Overhead 8% : $ 17,514.68
Total Cost : $ 236,448.24

If you need further informations, we can send you the scientific report and details of the expenses for each categories.

recipient_justification:
Responding to this office’s request to provide additional information on the disbursement of funds from the NIH/NIDDK grant - FAIN: RDK135218A, titled: “New approach for immune modulation against T1D.” As noted in your email:  “An ideal payment justification includes a specific description of: a) what the funds are for, b) why the funds are necessary, and c) why they are aligned with the award.”

A)	 What are the funds for?
The development of an effective treatment for Type 1 diabetes. A severe and costly disease that currently has no cure. Specifically, Research materials and supplies for the manufacture of EVOQ’s breakthrough NanoDisc technology for T1D, equipment and laboratory facility expenses, animal models, samples derived from T1D patients, and Research personnel.

B)	 Why are the funds necessary?
EVOQ is a small Biotech company with limited capital and resources. These funds support the T1D research and development plan outlined in the grant budget. Expense categories include Research materials and supplies for the manufacture of EVOQ’s breakthrough technology, equipment and laboratory facility expenses, animal models, samples derived from T1D patients, and Research personnel. As also noted in the grant, there is a huge unmet need for effective treatments for diabetes – a severe and costly disease with no cure. Some key facts: Nearly 40 million Americans, or 12% of the population, have diabetes. Two (2) million Americans have Type 1 diabetes, including about 304,000 children and adolescents. Because there is no cure, $413 billion was spent on diabetes in the United States in 2022. In addition, Diabetes is a leading cause of death in the United States, with the incidence of Type 1 diabetes is growing 3.5 times faster than the population (2.9% per year, vs. 0.8% per year)

C)	 Why are the funds aligned with the award?
These funds directly align with the award budget categories outlined in the grant. They include Research personnel, Laboratory personnel, necessary equipment, T1D-related materials and supplies, and laboratory facility expenses.

recipient_justification:
We received a project termination notice on March 27, 2025.  In the notice we were instructed to provide a final invoice for the actual expenses incurred by April 4, 2025. We followed the instructions and submitted the final invoice (Invoice 1) on April 4, 2025, which reflects the expenses incurred for the project period of performance  before the notification of project termination.  
Also note, there were some issues with the initial invoice submission on April 4, 2025 and this issue was finally resolved after we spoke with our program manager, Adam Barnhart on April 24, 2025 and he advised of the actions needed to be taken.

recipient_justification: Reimbursing meeting and travel expense, professional services and honoraria, personnel and fringe, and facilities and administrative expense as agreed in the grant award to lead a coordinated research consortium on the economics of Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's related dementias. The investigators and staff devoted time to circulating a call for proposals, with one group to be awarded to early career researchers and another to more senior scholars.  The investigator team has reviewed and ranked the submissions, with the advice of a review committee.  This team has also started planning for a research conference in Bethesda, MD in mid-June, and has assembled an invitation list to bring together members of the economics research community who are working on ADRD as well as other stakeholders from the medical and care delivery sectors.

recipient_justification: arch-Efforts this period expanded upon work done in January and February, with a focus on app-building and laying the groundwork for study implementation.  Primary technical and project management-related activities included: •	App-building activities: o	Development and iteration o	Incorporating feedback from team and content experts o	Resolving bugs and identifying areas for improvement o	Iterating on training content •	Preparing AI chatbot work (i.e., model-graded transcript review and evaluation) •	Co-developing REDCap database for data collection Study-related progress:  •Amending IRB application  •Coordinating with the standardized patient program •Continuing to operationalize study procedures and timeline with project team •Working with our EMPOWER (Harvard) partners to develop scenarios to be used throughout the intervention •Attending multiple weekly meetings and collaborating with partners to:  oFinalize study materials oPrepare for participant enrollment

recipient_justification: In March, the team made continued progress on chatbot improvements, EPIC integration testing, and study implementation, including patient engagement and feedback workflows. Efforts were also made to improve project coordination with partner institutions and to lay the groundwork for future development outputs.Technical Progress:Conducted ongoing EPIC testing: while data retrieval issues persisted in early March, the Dimagi team was later able to successfully query patient data in the MGH test environment. Testing will continue into April.Continued to monitor logs and took necessary action in case of any errors. Study Implementation:Four patients were enrolled.Continued collaborative work with MGH and UCLA on patient recruitment and engagement strategies.Developed engagement metrics assessing messaging volume and frequency. Added a question to the RedCap survey to surface technical issues limiting usage.Developed and refined the protocol for PRC, PCP, and patient qualitative interviews.

org_name: HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF

recipient_justification:
Alzheimer’s disease (AD) represents an urgent and growing public health crisis in the United States, with profound consequences for patients, caregivers, and the national economy. As the population ages, the financial burden of AD is projected to exceed $1 trillion annually—an estimate that does not fully capture the immense personal suffering and societal impact. Without intensified research efforts, both the human and economic toll will continue to escalate.
The spent funds were used to drive a critical research project at the Burke Neurological Institute (BNI), aimed at uncovering the underlying mechanisms that drive the onset and progression of Alzheimer’s disease. Specifically, the project investigates early dysfunction in neuronal activity and protein quality control systems within key brain regions, such as the locus coeruleus and hippocampus. By exploring the role of factors like sleep disturbances in these processes, the research seeks to identify early biomarkers and actionable targets for therapeutic intervention.
The requested spent funds were essential to enable the successful execution of this high-priority research at BNI. These expenses were aligned with the budget that was allocated to support core project components as follows:
•	Personnel: Funding supported a dedicated team of researchers, including the Contact Principal Investigator, a postdoctoral scientist, a wet lab research staff and two computational research scientists with specialized expertise in in vivo electrophysiology, behavioral analysis, advanced molecular techniques, and computational neuroscience. Their skills are critical to the project’s rigorous experimental design.
•	Equipment and Materials: The project funds were also spent for supplies required to operate state-of-the-art instrumentation and laboratory resources housed at BNI. These included advanced electrophysiology systems, surgical equipment, and specialized biological and chemical reagents that were essential for conducting the proposed experiments.
•	Operational Expenses: Funding also covered operational costs, including the care and maintenance of in vivo models, travel for scientific collaboration and dissemination of results, and data management infrastructure aligned with NIH FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) data principles.
BNI’s research is at the leading edge of AD investigation, utilizing innovative methodologies and disease-relevant models to identify novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. The anticipated outcomes have the potential to inform earlier diagnosis and facilitate the development of urgently needed treatments for Alzheimer's disease.
The resources expended as well as future monies for this research represents a strategic and necessary step in addressing the mounting challenges posed by Alzheimer’s disease. The expenditures were not only justified—but were pivotal to advancing the science that may ultimately reduce the burden of this devastating condition. The successful execution of this project is directly contingent upon past and future use of these funds. We are aligned with and thank you for the outstanding work you are doing to assure that research dollars are being spent in a way that is consonant with the optimal future personal and financial health of the country.

recipient_justification: This payment covers only a single project. Among the 6 tasks that Exhalix has planned for the current SBIR Phase II studies awarded we are currently focusing on Tasks 2, 4 and 5, including further small and large animal testing of the alpha prototype (repeat experiments) with help from the engineering team at Exhalix on providing disposable modules for the prototypes. During this period, our team was heavily focused on the development and testing of the beta prototype planned for testing at TAMU starting in late June. The requested payment covers direct project cost and F&A expenses for the balance of the total expenses on this project to date ($98,450), plus a fee of 4.25% agreed on the award ($4,183), for a total of $102,633 draw requested.

recipient_justification:
This payment request is necessary to cover immediate project expenses for the period of Jan 3, 2025 to Feb 27, 2025.  The funds will be used for the following purposes:
•	Personnel costs: 14,964.66 (salary and fringe benefits for BC Cancer project staff)
•	Catering: $628.31 ( In-person Annual CISNET meeting)
•	Purchased Services:  $34,501.99 (external expert services for development of the consortium smoking history generator and the tobacco control policy tool, Cornerstone Systems)
•	Subawards:  $33,487.86 (Erasmus Medical Center subaward)
The requested funds are required at this time to ensure timely commencement of project activities and to fulfill contractual obligations with vendors and staff.  All expenses are in accordance with the approved project aims and budget and comply with federal and organizational regulations.

recipient_justification: Based on our review, the activities covered by this statement of work include a proposal “to contribute knowledge about how immigrant policies may influence Latino mental health and health care access in rural regions by conducting a multilevel, cross-sectional study of the impact of policy contexts, social climates, and Latinos’ direct encounters with institutions that implement policy.”  We do not believe that this type of observational or empirical research violates federal anti-discrimination laws.  On that basis, we intend to draw down funds to carry out the project absent a statement to the contrary from you by 4/3/2025. recipient_justification:
The purpose of the Role of Adiponectin in Reversal of Age-related Vascular Dysfunction activity is  to determine whether adiponectin plays a role in 1) the vascular dysfunction that occurs with advancing age, and 2) the ability of exercise training to promote vascular resiliency and reverse age-related vascular dysfunction. Adiponectin is a protein that circulates in high levels in the blood and which has known protective effects on the cardiovascular system. Aging impairs vascular function, but late-life exercise can reverse much of the vascular dysfunction related to advancing age.

The budget line-item categories for this reimbursement request are Salary ($11,161.55), Graduate Student Salary ($6,317.33), Benefits ($10,538.49), Student Salary ($924.00), Student Benefits ($7.70), Contractual ($3,692.14), Commodities ($973.29), Subcontracts ($21,525.23), and Indirect Costs ($28,672.85).

recipient_justification: During the current period, work continued on calibration of the hybrid material (HM) scintillator, including correction for geometrical effects related to differences in the beam image magnification and intensity primarily due to beam dimensional differences in the distance over the tilted scintillator plane field-of-view to the camera lens and sensor, as well as image perspective distortion, etc. The mechanical calibration system was finished and tested in April with a 2.4 mCi, Sr-90 beta source moving across the 15x23-cm scintillator area in a grid pattern composed of 1 cm steps in both the X & Y directions. The full travel time with calibration analysis takes about 15 minutes. For actual FLASH beam analysis ~2000 images are collected and analyzed in real-time, that is within ~0.1 seconds (i.e., 50 microseconds per image with the camera operating at 20,000 frames per second).  Work is still progressing on software and firmware improvements on the FPGA board.

recipient_justification:
To reimburse for the contracted costs to for Dr. Basen-Engquist, Dr. Raber and the scientific team provided scientific oversight of the study, collaborating closely with the HOPE Clinic team on community assessment, intervention planning, recruitment, data collection, and analysis. They also managed regulatory aspects, including IRB approval and protocol amendments, and oversaw the study's establishment, budget, and personnel. Dr. Shete advised on study design, conduct, analysis, implementation, evaluation, and interpretation, ensuring compliance with data sharing requirements.
MD Anderson's institutional resources, including the Joint Center for Geospatial Research and the Impact Evaluation Core, further supported the project by providing expertise in population health data, public health intelligence, and community needs assessment. MD Anderson personnel, including Research Data Coordinator, Program Manager, and 2 students, assisted with coordination with HOPE Clinic, recruitment, data collection, quality assurance, meeting organization, and data management.

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $72,124.68 on the DHHS – NIH grant number 5U01HG011176-05. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period April 6, 2025, through April 26, 2025 for expenses approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Genomic risk in clinic care to promote health equity in New York City patients. 

Personnel 	$32,578.11
Fringe Benefit	$10,099.22
Indirect Cost	$29,447.35
Total		$72,124.68

It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with RFA HG-19- 014, 45 CFR Part 75 and the NIH Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

recipient_justification: The Collaborative Islet Transplant Registry (CITR; wwww.citregistry.org) is focused on expediting progress and promoting safety in islet/beta cell transplantation to better treat the chronic illness of Type 1 diabetes. Emmes serves as the Data and Statistical Coordinating Center (DSCC) for CITR and works with the NIDDK to administer this grant. Emmes provides support for identifying and maintaining the network of international clinical sites performing islet/beta cell transplantation, registering all new transplants performed at these sites, collecting longitudinal data on all patients receiving transplants, and developing reports, manuscripts and presentations to disseminate findings to the field with the goal of improving patient outcomes for Type 1 diabetes. Emmes worked at risk during from January 2025 through March 2025 while awaiting the award of carryover funding. This invoice reflects the cost for providing support during this timeframe.

recipient_justification: We are rolling out cervical cancer screening for our intervention cohort and are also doing individual as well as group education in the intervention communities.  We have done 6 rounds of screening using HPV DNA testing and are now supporting the women to undergo follow-up diagnostic testing when there is a positive test.   We are also working across 9 hospitals to provide technical assistance and training so the screening processes can be embedded within the existing public healthcare infrastructure.   We are also providing training to community liaisons who are supporting the women enrolled in our study to undergo screening and also helping educate them on the benefits of screening and general well-being.  We have also developed our protocol paper and are in the process of submitting that for publication.  This manuscript describes our three- arm cluster randomized trial and the outcomes we are planning to achieve.

recipient_justification:
Items in our March draw are covered in the Approved Budget and Budget Justification info below.				
				
LOC ID	             Project	                Account	Amount    Description
RGM136885A	RNIHX0001260601	523100	 3,054.62 	Salaries-Graduate Assistants
RGM136885A	RNIHX0001260601	524100	 306.80 	Salaries-Student Assistants
RGM136885A	RNIHX0001260601	714102	 25.41 	     S&M-Lab Chemicals & Supplies
RGM136885A	RNIHX0001260601	742100	 3,340.00 	Publications and Printing
RGM136885A	RNIHX0001260601	951100	 3,430.69 	Allocated OH-IDC Spons Agreements
			                                           Total  10,157.52 	
				
From NOGA SECTION I – AWARD DATA – 5R01GM136885-03				
Cumulative Award Calculations for this Budget Period (U.S. Dollars)				
Salaries and Wages 				 196,526.00 
Fringe Benefits				 61,833.00 
Personnel Costs (Subtotal) 				 258,359.00 
Materials & Supplies 				 24,696.00 
Travel 				 2,694.00 
Publication Costs 				 2,395.00 
Federal Direct Costs				 288,144.00 
Federal F&A Costs				 146,953.00 
Approved Budget				 435,097.00 
Total Amount of Federal Funds Authorized (Federal Share)				 435,097.00 
TOTAL FEDERAL AWARD AMOUNT				 435,097.00 
				
From Budget Justification				
B. OTHER PERSONNEL				
2 Associate Research Scientists (each effort = 6.0 calendar months).				
He will characterize three novel tungstoenzymes. He will also assist in directing two graduate students to grow				
the gut microorganisms and determine their metal contents, to purify their assigned tungstoenzymes and to				
determine the catalytic activities of each (Aims 1-3).				
				
F. OTHER DIRECT COSTS				
F.1 Materials and Supplies				
The requested funds (Y2 = $21,715) will be used as follows: chemicals, include reagents for enzyme assays				
and media and gases for growing the microbes ($8,000); chromatographic materials for the purification of both				
native and recombinant proteins, including Q-Sepharose, Hydroxyapatite, Phenyl Sepharose, and Ni-affinity				
resins and columns ($5,000); routine supplies, such as cuvettes, syringes, serum stoppers, and vials for				
enzyme assays ($6,000); cryomaterials; including liquid nitrogen for routine storage of cells, cell extracts, and				
purified enzymes and proteins ($1,000); molecular biology supplies, including enzymes and primers for gene				
cloning and over-expression ($5,000); reagents and consumable for metabolomics analyses ($5,500) and for				
UPLC-LC-HRMS ($2,500). In addition, in year 1, additional funds ($10,000) are requested for chromatography				
columns that will be subsequently used with the requested yearly supply of chromatographic materials.				
				
F. 2 Publication Costs				
These are estimated at $3,200 for year 2 (in one open-access journal and one traditional journal).				
				
H. INDIRECT COSTS				
The federal negotiated indirect rate for the University of Georgia Research Foundation, Inc. is 51% MTDC for				
on-campus research projects per the F&A Rate Agreement negotiated with the Department of Health and				
Human Services

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $58,290.30 on the DHHS – NIH grant number 5R01HL173203-02. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period April 6, 2025, through April 26, 2025: Personnel $26,329.24, Fringe Benefits $8,162.06, and Indirect Costs $23,799.00 subtotal $58,290.30 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, The Chromatin Remodeling Factor ARID1a and the Epigenetic Landscape In Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension. It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75 and the NIH Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

recipient_justification: This grant project looks at the role of ASIC1 channels in ionic entry, regulation of certain CSC markers, and utilization of a suitable range of NB cell lines and NB-derived CSC, which is different from the current research paradigm in Neuroblastoma (NB) studies which is the most common and lethal childhood extracranial solid tumor. The novel knowledge obtained from our study has the potential to significantly impact the outcome of NB patients and contribute to ion transport proteins studies in other types of tumors. Grant funds were used in alignment with the objective established in the grant to ensure meaningful progress toward the intended outcomes of the award. Expenditure covered personnel costs, including salaries and fringe benefits, as well as lab equipment supply services and maintenance and office supplies for the critical services necessary for the effective implementation of the grant activities.

recipient_justification: Ligand-Based Virtual Screening (VS), medicinal chemistry (medchem), compound procurement and program management (PM) for the purpose of addressing the STTR Grant Aim 2.Use advanced platforms including Openeye’s Brood and Orion, Eurofins’ SAFIRE ADMET predictions, & Chemical Computing Group’s MOE, to perform a Ligand-Based VS, apply ADMET predictions, & evaluate molecular dynamics simulations. Use of Eurofins DiscoveryAITM’s complex tools allows interrogation of 20 billion available make-on-demand compounds in a highly efficient manner. org_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

recipient_justification: Luna Labs collaborated and conducted a PK/ADME/biodistribution study of the delivery vehicle using radio labeling with 89Zr. We worked on the excretion mass balance study and prepared the delivery vehicle, short carbon nanotubes, for radiolabeling at UVA. UVA worked on characterizing radiolabeled short carbon nanotubes. Mice have been purchased and will be ready for the study in approximately a month. We prepared the second dose for Columbia University to support the efficacy study using HIS mice. Four optimized candidate formulations and one control were prepared and delivered to Columbia who have completed the second dose, which was administered intramuscularly to HIS mice. Columbia worked on ELISA, ELISPOT, and ICCS for animal serum samples. We also initiated discussions with a GMP partner, NanoComposite/Fortis Life, to develop a protocol for scaling up the delivery vehicle and its formulation candidates. Costs include labor, materials, ODC, & travel for this SBIR Phase II.

Activity: Upstream process development, Amber250 clone selection study, and upstream process implementation (harvest supply)

Therefore, the total amount requested at this stage is $56,000.

recipient_justification: The requested payment covers personnel salaries, fringe benefits, and indirect costs associated with direct labor on the Small Business Innovation and Research NIH-awarded grant SAI128974B (“Commercialization of PANDAA qDx for rapid drug resistance genotyping of protease inhibitor ART failures in resource-limited settings”). Specifically, this supports the Principal Investigator, Scientist, Head of Product and Quality, and Product Development Associate, whose roles involve assay development, clinical evaluation, and validation of PANDAA technology for rapid and accurate detection of HIV drug resistance mutations. These activities align directly with the project's goal of demonstrating assay sensitivity, specificity, and comparative effectiveness against established genotyping methods, as outlined in the original grant budget justification. Funding these roles is essential to successfully complete clinical validations and facilitate the transition toward broader clinical implementation, fulfilling NIH objectives for improved HIV treatment outcomes. All requested funds are compliant with allowable costs per NIH Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $54,556.52 on the DHHS – NIH grant number 5R01HL159433-04. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period April 6, 2025, through April 26, 2025 for expenses approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Mechanistic registry to study whether infection with Corona Virus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) accelerates atherosclerotic plaque progression. 

Personnel 	$24,642.72
Fringe Benefit	$7,639.24
Indirect Cost	$22,274.56
Total		$54,556.52

It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities. recipient_justification: Funds are requested to support supply purchases, personnel costs, and approved domestic contracts for the preclinical development of an innovative MHCII-targeted immunotherapy drug for the treatment of pancreatic cancer. Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest cancers and kills over 50,000 Americans each year. Cancer immunotherapy holds the key to saving and improving the lives of patients and families affected by pancreatic cancer, but existing immunotherapies have thus far been ineffective. Our approach has the potential to change that trend. All requested funds were outlined in the grant proposal and approved by the awarding agency.

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $53,098.87 on the DHHS – NIH grant number 5KL2TR004421-03. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period April 6, 2025, through April 26, 2025: Personnel $37,531.01, Fringe Benefits $11,634.61, and Indirect Costs $3,933.25 subtotal $53,098.87 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Institutional Career Development Core. It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with PAR-18-940, 45 CFR Part 75 and the NIH Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai
